questions.text: What is the enzyme deficiency in Pompe’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase

  • Pompe’s disease is a muscle glycogen storage disorder, also known as Glycogen storage disorder type I,I which is caused by the deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase.

Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II)

Definition

Glycogen storage disorder caused by deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

 

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells

 

Forms
  • Infantile Pompe disease (IPD) - Severe
  • Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) - Less Severe

Clinical Features
  • IPD: Hypotonia, muscle weakness, feeding difficulties, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • LOPD: Proximal limb-girdle muscle weakness, respiratory muscle involvement, cardiac rhythm disturbances

 

Laboratory Findings
  • Elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH
  • Cardiomegaly on chest X-ray (infantile form)
  • ECG changes- shortened P-R interval, tall QRS complexes

Treatment
  • Enzyme replacement therapy with alglucosidase alfa
  • High-protein diet (for LOPD)
  • Histopathology findings: muscle biopsy/ cardiac biopsy has vacuoles within muscle fibres which stain with PAS strongly (glycogen is pas positive, diastase sensitive)


Glucose 6 phosphatase (Option B) is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. Deficiency of this enzyme is seen in Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type I), not in Pompe's disease.

Muscle phosphorylase (Option C), also known as myophosphorylase, is an enzyme involved in glycogenolysis (the breakdown of glycogen into glucose) in muscle tissue. A deficiency of muscle phosphorylase leads to McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V), characterized by exercise intolerance and muscle cramps.

Phosphofructokinase (Option D) is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the breakdown of glucose to produce energy. Deficiency of phosphofructokinase leads to Tarui disease (glycogen storage disease type VII), characterized by exercise intolerance and muscle weakness.

questions.text: All of the following tests are done for screening in patients with Turner’s syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - ANA

  • The ANA test is not typically performed as part of Turner mosaic screening. ANA testing is primarily used to help diagnose autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other connective tissue diseases.

Condition

Evaluation

Cardiac Abnormalities

EKG (for prolonged QT interval), Blood pressure (upper and lower extremities), Echocardiogram (Option C) or Cardiac MRI for anomalies.

Cognitive Function/Learning Disabilities

Special education assessments and evaluations at school.

Hearing Loss

Serial audiology evaluations (Option B) every 3 years in children, and every 5 years in adults.

Renal Abnormalities

Renal ultrasound at diagnosis.

Ovarian Failure

Serum FSH and AMH at 10-11 years.

Osteoporosis/Bone Health

Screening for low bone mineral density and fractures. Annual screening for scoliosis during growth hormone therapy.

Celiac Disease

Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies at 2 years, and every 2 years thereafter.

Autoimmune Thyroiditis

TSH and free or total T4 measurements annually starting at 4 years.

Liver Disease

ALT, AST, GGT, and alkaline phosphatase annually after 10 years.

Metabolic Syndrome

Hemoglobin A1c annually, starting at 10 years.

Lipid panel annually if cardiovascular risk factors are present.

Vitamin D Deficiency

Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D at 9-11 years, and every 2-3 years thereafter.

Gonadoblastoma

Screening for Y chromosome if marker chromosome elements are present or virilization develops.

Screening Laboratory Tests

Fasting blood glucose (Option D), glycated haemoglobin, serum creatinine, and urinalysis at 10 years and above to screen for diabetes mellitus and kidney disease.

questions.text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chest X-ray

Explanation:

Importance of Chest X-ray in Central Line Placement

  • Initial Assessment:
    • A chest X-ray should be performed immediately after internal jugular and subclavian line placement to confirm correct catheter placement and rule out iatrogenic pneumothorax.
       
  • Post-Procedure Verification:
    • It is crucial to verify catheter placement and ensure no complications, like pneumothorax, following the procedure.
       
  • Ipsilateral Side Approach:
    • If the internal jugular central venous line (CVL) insertion fails, move to the ipsilateral subclavian vein.
    • A chest X-ray or ultrasound should be performed before attempting the opposite side to prevent bilateral pneumothoraces.


Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult patient with a pulsatile swelling in the neck below the jaw angle that causes an outward expansile impulse, based on the findings of an MRI angiography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carotid body tumour

Explanation:

  • In the above scenario, there is a pulsatile swelling, and on MRI angiography, it shows Lyre's sign which is the splaying of internal and external arteries, which is diagnostic of carotid body tumour.

 

Carotid Body Tumor (CBT)

  • CBT, also known as paraganglioma or chemodectoma, is a rare benign neck tumour originating from the neural crest at the adventitia of the common carotid artery bifurcation.
  • CBTs grow slowly, have a low cancer rate, and are not significantly associated with age or gender, though some suggest a slightly higher incidence in women.
  • The pathogenesis is unclear but is linked to chronic hypoxia and mutations in mitochondrial oxygen-sensitive genes.

Diagnosis:

  • B-mode Ultrasonography:
    • It shows solid, hypoechoic tumours near blood vessels.
       
  • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA):
    • DSA visualized tumour blood supply and the displacement of arteries, with a diagnostic coincidence rate of 100%.
       
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
    • MRI showed tumours at the bifurcation of the carotid artery with compression and displacement of arteries.
    • Tumours appeared as round or round-like masses, showing heterogeneous or high signals on T2-WI.
       
  • The Lyre sign refers to the splaying of the internal and external carotid by a carotid body tumour.
  • It is classically described in angiography it is also visible in CT angiography.

Treatment:

  • Surgical Resection: The most effective treatment for CBTs.
  • Other Modalities: Radiotherapy, embolization, and combination therapy can also be considered.

Incorrect Options:

Grave’s disease (Option A) is a hyperthyroid condition with bulging eyes, and the neck swelling is not pulsatile.

Branchial cysts (Option B) are small fluid-filled sacs that look like lumps under the skin on the side of the neck and are more common in children than adults.

A thymic cyst (Option C) is a benign mediastinal disease and presents with dyspnea, chest pain, cough, hoarseness and dysphagia.

questions.text: A patient who is a tour guide of Mount Everest presented with blisters on her hand as shown in the figure below. She has severe pain and on examination is erythematous and tender. Which of the following is used in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Apply heat to the area and cast it as soon as possible

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NSAID’s

Explanation:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation associated with blisters.

  • The recommended approach includes protecting the blister, keeping it clean, and using pain-relieving measures such as NSAIDs, if necessary.
  • Avoid Sun Exposure: Keep the affected area out of the sun to prevent further damage.
  • Skin Care: Apply cool compresses, aloe vera gel, or lotion to soothe the skin. Avoid local anaesthetic creams.
  • Blister Care: Wash ruptured blisters with soap and water and cover with moist gauze.

Options A and B are incorrect.

Pentoxyphylline (Option C) is a medication that can improve blood flow and is sometimes used in the treatment of vascular disorders. This is not indicated here.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented the findings shown in the given image. What is this physical finding called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clubbing

Explanation:

  • The image shows typical findings of clubbing of fingers, seen in various cardiopulmonary conditions. Clubbing is not always irreversible and can be reversible in certain conditions.

Clubbing of fingers

Definition
  • Enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes
  • Proliferation of connective tissue
  • Particularly on the dorsal surface
  • Changes at the base of clubbed nail

Pathophysiology
  • Connective tissue proliferation
  • Exact mechanism unknown
  • Platelet-derived growth factors implicated

Clinical Signs
  • Bulbous Enlargement of the Distal Phalanges
  • Loss of the Normal Angle Between the Nail and the Nailbed (Lovibond’s Angle)
  • Increased Sponginess of the Soft Tissue at the Base of the Nail
  • Nail Changes:
  • Nail flattening/nail curvature
  • Hippocratic fingers: The tips of the fingers become enlarged, and the nails curve downward

Clinical tests

Schamroth’s Sign:

  • Normal: A small diamond-shaped window should be visible between the nails when the fingers are positioned in this way.
  • Positive Schamroth’s Sign: The window disappears, and there is no gap between the nails, indicating the loss of the normal angle at the nail bed.

Associated Conditions
  • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Lung cancer
  • Tuberculosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease

Key Features
  • Can be hereditary or acquired
  • May be reversible in certain circumstances
  • Associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
  • Can cause pain and arthritis-like changes

 

Spoon-shaped nails (koilonychia) (Option A): The nail abnormality is characterized by thin, fragile nails with a concave appearance, either horizontally or vertically oriented. The nail plate appears to be depressed in the centre and bent outward at the edges.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option B) presents as repeated constriction of blood vessels in the fingers and toes, typically triggered by cold temperatures or stress.

Pallor (Option C) refers to a noticeable decrease in the normal colour and tone of the skin or mucous membranes, which may occur due to changes in blood flow, anaemia, or other unclear factors.

questions.text: Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for biting a 10-year-old child who presented with symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, tongue fasciculation, hypersalivation, dilated pupils, and mild erythema at the site of the wound? The child recalls that the animal had a curved tail pointing upwards.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Scorpion

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and the characteristics of the animal with a curved tail pointing upwards point to the possibility of the animal being a scorpion.

Less dangerous scorpions:

  • Local pain, swelling, and burning sensation
  • Symptoms resolve in a few hours
  • Possible allergic reactions to venom

Bark scorpions (e.g., Centruroides species):

  • Intense pain, paresthesia, and hyperesthesia (worsened by tapping)
  • Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements
  • Excessive salivation, sweating, and difficulty handling secretions
  • Nausea, vomiting, slurred speech
  • Muscle twitching, jerking, and shaking (may resemble seizures)
  • Tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypertension, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis
  • Respiratory arrest, especially in children and the elderly

Venomous scorpions (e.g., Tityus serrulatus, Leiurus quinquestriatus):

  • Hypertensive crises, arrhythmias, myocardial damage
  • Pulmonary oedema, central nervous toxicity

Other species (e.g., Hemiscorpius lepturus):

  • Pain, hemolysis, tissue necrosis (delayed onset)
  • Systemic complications: hemoglobinuria, acute kidney injury

General symptoms of envenomations:

  • Immediate sharp local pain
  • Edema, ecchymosis, and burning sensation
  • Symptoms generally resolve within hours for most species

Treatment of scorpion sting:

  • Identification of the scorpion species is essential for determining treatment, as stings from non-lethal species typically only require basic care.
  • Non-lethal stings: Most stings cause local discomfort and can be managed at home with ice packs, analgesics, or antihistamines. Patients should return to the emergency department if cranial-nerve or neuromuscular symptoms develop.
  • Severe envenomations: Aggressive supportive care and careful use of antivenom can prevent deaths from more dangerous stings.
  • Initial measures: Keeping the patient calm, applying pressure dressings, and using cold packs can reduce venom absorption.
  • Treatment for symptoms: Continuous IV infusion of midazolam can control agitation and muscle movements, but close monitoring is needed due to the risk of respiratory arrest, especially when sedatives or narcotics are used.
  • Management of complications:
    • Hypertension and pulmonary oedema: Managed with nifedipine, nitroprusside, hydralazine, or prazosin.
    • Bradycardia: Managed with atropine.
  • Antivenin: FDA-approved antivenin (C. sculpturatus IgG F(ab')2 in horse serum) is available in some countries and can rapidly reverse cranial-nerve dysfunction and muscular symptoms when administered intravenously.

 

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient has a long arm span, hypermobile joints and hypermobile lens. What is the defective protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fibrillin-1

Explanation:

  • The presentation describes Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to defective fibrillin-1, an essential component of microfibrils that provide structural integrity to connective tissue and regulate TGF-β signaling.
  • Clinical features include tall stature, disproportionately long limbs (increased arm span-to-height ratio), joint hypermobility, lens subluxation (typically upward), and cardiovascular involvement (aortic root dilatation, aneurysm).

Incorrect Options:

Collagen (Option B): Defects cause disorders such as Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and osteogenesis imperfecta, which may have joint hypermobility but not the full Marfan phenotype with lens dislocation and long arm span.

Elastin (Option C): Deficiency is associated with conditions like supravalvular aortic stenosis and Williams syndrome, but not the Marfan skeletal and ocular features.

Keratin (Option D): Structural protein in epithelial cells; mutations lead to skin and hair disorders, not connective tissue or cardiovascular manifestations.

questions.text: A skin graft was performed on an immunocompromised patient using tissue from another immunocompromised individual. Weeks later, the patient developed contractures and systemic symptoms. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Rejection due to recipient T8 cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Graft-versus-host disease:

Explanation:

  • Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs when immunocompetent donor T lymphocytes recognize recipient tissues as foreign and mount an immune response.
  • This typically happens in immunocompromised recipients who are unable to reject the donor T cells.
  • In the context of a skin graft (especially from another immunocompromised individual where donor lymphocytes may survive),
  • GVHD can cause systemic symptoms (fever, rash, liver dysfunction, diarrhea) along with local changes like skin contractures.

Incorrect Options:

Graft failure (Option B): Results from the inability of the graft to establish blood supply, leading to necrosis — it occurs early, not weeks later, and does not cause systemic immune symptoms.

Rejection due to recipient T8 cells (Option C): This is host-versus-graft rejection, not GVHD, and requires an immunocompetent recipient — which is not the case here.

Delayed wound healing (Option D): Common in immunocompromised states but does not explain systemic features or the contractures caused by immune-mediated damage.
